1111296899867394054.text:
Flat earthers are a social problem, not an educational one. If you ostracize people, they will cling to other excluded people and fester in their seclusion building ever more preposterous justifications.
See also: Birthers, Truthers, Pizzagate, Fake Moon Landers......https://twitter.com/neiltyson/status/1111295662920888320Â â€¦

1111311457369640963.text:
What's funny is that if I tell people that antiseptic lifestyles lead to hardened, resistant bacteria, people will generally agree.
When I say that social exclusion leads to hardened resistant conspiracies, somehow I'm a weirdo.

1111333039412596736.text: People aren't bacteria? Ok, I'm torn there. It's also more complicated, but isn't that normally so.

1111313817877864448.text: I disagree. I think deplatforming and exclusion limits the spread of harmful ideas and denies people the social support framework to form resistance.

1111342241283481611.text:
TBF People are NOT bacteria, and I use it only as an analogy. 
Agree that its not an easy problem, but isnt that exactly WHY we have to talk about it?
I think my example list is at least indicative, if less than conclusive, of my premise.

1111344773087068161.text: People aren't bacteria, true, but to quote one of my late nemeses "You humans are just a virus waiting to spread, and I will destroy you before you reach the stars, while your destruction is confined to this miserable rock." My point is, some views deserve to be deplatformed.

1111315572388777984.text:
I've seen those arguments and I disagree. Deplatforming doesnt halt the spread of harmful ideas. It turns echo chambers into petrie dishes.
If anything there should be more people reaching out and resocializing people.

1111345516279943168.text:
But we dont deplatform views. We deplatform PEOPLE.
I want the luntaic finges stopped as much as anyone, but I have concerns that the exclusion only makes them more resolute.
Similar to the complaints that Prisons cause prisoners by giving criminals a place to 'compare notes'.

1111347200515325952.text: I actually agree with you, but there is also the problem that giving someone a platform lends their views legitimacy and if their views are harmful (anti-vaxxers being an example) then giving them a platform carries it's own risks.

1111319867565719552.text: The evidence shows otherwise. Google 'deplatforming effectiveness'.

1111347795049500672.text: Anti-Vaxxers are a great example of what Im talking about. What we see is the result.

1111348895458750464.text: They don't do it in secluded sections. They do it on the platforms they are given.  These people aren't finding back-alley anti-vax groups, they have subreddits and FB groups to reinforce these beliefs.

1111341059701907457.text:
Sorry about the lag. After looking at the research (and there is very little of it) it seems like the most that can be said is that deplatforming only really decreases the behaviour ON THAT PLATFORM.

1111341479707004928.text:
you cannot erase an idea by banning it. 
The only way to 'destroy' and idea is by presenting a *better* idea that can out compete it.

1111351556019011584.text:
I understand that and agree that its a problem. But it doesnt get big until its had time to fester. To grow. Normally in isolation.
If you catch a lunatic idea BEFORE it can establish a social support network, Id bet the odds are better that you can renormalize that person.

1111343435108237313.text: There are already plenty of better ideas than flat earth and other conspiracy theories. Deplatforming does not 'erase' an idea, it prevents the spread of the idea and minimizes the social structure for conspiracists.

1111343934918283265.text:
Agree and isolating them GUARANTEES that they will not have access to those superior ideas. THATS the problem.
They flee to toher websites (see the spike in google searches for AJ), or find other ways to interact. They HAVE to. Its (often) what (totally) defines them.

1111353670602510336.text: That logic is difficult for me to see when we use anti-vaxxing as our example. It very much grew entirely because the internet gave it such a broad platform. If it had been caught and kept from spreading early on, like a virus, we might well be safe from it now.

1111344239445753857.text: How does it guarantee that? We aren't shutting them off from the internet at large or preventing them from using services for non-conspiratorial ideas.

1111358407531999232.text: I too have trouble really articulating it. Honestly, Im not really indigenous to SocMed. I do however wonder HOW these people 'won' converts in the face of years of data and evidence because ONE guy wrote ONE (since disproven) paper.

1111764712658792449.text: I'm slow on this one. Sorry. Some notions don't deserve a platform,such as anti-vaxxers. I hold the same view of young-earth creationists. I'm jut not sure how we do it.

1111772385680728064.text:

1111345485204332545.text: We can't force a person to adapt new thinking. Conspiracists must choose to do it themselves. So the benefit of deplatforming is that we prevent the spread of the idea and socially isolate the person to encourage that change. Leaving them to flourish has no benefit.

1111345995449806848.text:

1111347105963143175.text: Leaving them exposed to society increases their risk on society. This is why we deplatform ISIS and terrorist propaganda. A superior idea does not prevent online radicalization, and allowing it to flourish increases its risk to society.

1111347859377569793.text:

1112083068037332992.text: We were ready for it. This is arguably the golden age of nerddom. We are indigenous to this and have some coping skills, but even WE are overwhelmed by the blind fealty, information overload, inflation of minutiae and shockingly desolate loneliness.
